concept.title: Print versus non-print metadata
concept.shortdesc: You can use condition attributes in topic elements, the print attribute in the topicref element, separate ditamaps, or a combination of these approaches when you need to produce different print and non-print versions of the same document.

conbody.p: There are a number of ways of differentiating Web-only and print-only content, or other medium-dependent conditions. The best method will depend on the semantics involved, and the particular scenario.

In many cases, marking up content using otherprops attribute values of, for example, manual_only and web_only may be appropriate. If the reason for the differentiation relates to the different audiences for print and Web deliverables, then the audience attribute would be a better choice. In the same way, if the reason for differentiation was that you are producing two separate document products, such as a book to be sold on the Web and a book to be sold in bookshops, the product attribute is more suitable.

The topicref element in the ditamap has a print attribute with valid values of yes and no. If you are simply wanting to exclude complete topics from the print version of a document, this attribute should be used.

If you have some common and some different topics for print and Web versions, you may find that creating two ditamaps, one for print and one for Web, is a better approach than applying conditions to the topicref elements in a single ditamap.

section.title: Rationale

lq.reftitle: Andy Hall, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: Is it good practice to use @otherprops to markup content for web and PDF outputs (e.g., using otherprops values of "manual_only" for PDF deliverables, and "web_only" for HTML deliverables)? Or are there better, smarter ways to generate outputs for HTML and PDF outputs?
section.p: Deborah Pickett observed that although it's not wrong, and although there may be occasions when it's the best way, the nature of the content will dictate whether it's right or not.

lq.reftitle: Deborah Pickett, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p: If web_only and manual_only are independent of each other (i.e., you could have one or both or neither set) then conditional processing is a good fit. But given their names, they look like they are either/or exactly-one choices (what I call "disjoint-union" from set theory). Conditional processing is a poor solution for disjoint unions, for several reasons, one in this case being that you have to police correct use of only one inclusion in the ditaval file.

For comparison, what I'd do in that situation is have two separate maps. They would share almost all of their content via mapref, except > for the bits where they differ. I'd consider using the @print > attribute on topicrefs that I don't want to turn up in the print output.

lq.reftitle: Su-Laine Yeo, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: No, you can't use the @print attribute on most elements. In general, marking content as PDF-only or as help-only is considered kind of philosophically wrong by XML purists. The ideal way to go about it is to ask yourself why you'd want something to be PDF-only or help-only and then use markup which more directly reflects the reason.

lq.reftitle: Sowmya Kannan, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: Hi, Are there any best practices / guidelines for content that may be delivered as HTML and PDF? For e.g. it would be better to not include object tags to run applets, flash objects etc. directly in the topic. Topics with object tags may not be suitable for pdf outputs. How do we handle such cases? Should we include conditional text based on type of output? What are some other cases to watch out for?
